title: 108_hr2876
content: The Act may be cited as the "Quit Smoking Incentive and Opportunity Act of 2003". Congress finds that tobacco use is a leading cause of preventable deaths in the United States, with millions of Americans at risk of premature death due to tobacco dependence. Clinical studies have shown that both pharmacological treatments and counseling are effective in helping individuals quit smoking. The effectiveness of tobacco dependence treatment can be increased when counseling is combined with pharmacological treatment. Nicotine Replacement Therapy is often not covered by Medicare or private insurance, costing around $300 for a 10-week course. The Guide to Community Preventive Services and Clinical Practice Guideline recommend reducing out-of-pocket costs for tobacco cessation treatments. Current law allows deductions for cessation counseling and nicotine-withdrawal drugs, but most filers do not itemize. SEC. 3. REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR AMOUNTS PAID TO ASSIST INDIVIDUALS TO CEASE USING TOBACCO PRODUCTS. This section introduces a new refundable credit for expenses to help individuals quit using tobacco products. A credit is allowed for qualified tobacco use cessation expenses paid by an individual, limited to $300 for certain expenses and $100 for others. Qualified expenses are for FDA-approved products promoting tobacco reduction. The text chunk discusses counseling for cessation of tobacco use, including diagnostic, therapy, and counseling services provided by healthcare professionals. This is part of a broader effort to reduce tobacco use among individuals. State regulatory mechanism provided by State law for services recommended in 'Treating Tobacco Use and Dependence: A Clinical Practice Guideline' published by the Public Health Service in June 2000, or any subsequent modification, and other effective services recognized by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Technical amendment to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The United States Code is amended to include section 36 after section 35. Section 35A allows for certain expenses to help individuals quit using tobacco products. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act.
